results.abstract: Lunar Prospector, small unmanned spacecraft, is ready to embark on trip to Moon; it is scheduled for launching on Jan 5 at Cape Canaveral, Fla; after journey of 4 1/2 days, craft should swing into lunar orbit on Jan 10 and begin 18 months of gathering data on Moon's structure, composition and potentially useful resources for future interplanetary exploration; one of its priorities is to answer question, is there water on Moon (M)

headline.main: Seeking Water on Moon In New NASA Mission

results.snippet: Twenty-five years after the last Apollo astronaut left the Moon, a small unmanned spacecraft is ready to embark on a return trip, the first mission since then designed expressly for lunar exploration. One of its priorities is to answer the question,...
results.lead_paragraph: Twenty-five years after the last Apollo astronaut left the Moon, a small unmanned spacecraft is ready to embark on a return trip, the first mission since then designed expressly for lunar exploration. One of its priorities is to answer the question, Is there water on the Moon? The 660-pound cylindrical spacecraft, Lunar Prospector, is scheduled for launching at 8:31 P.M. on Monday at Cape Canaveral, Fla. After a journey of four and a half days, the craft should swing into a lunar orbit on Saturday and begin 18 months of gathering data on the Moon's structure, composition and potentially useful resources for future interplanetary exploration.

results.abstract: David Wolf, American astronaut aboard Mir space station, makes first space walk to check outer hull for possible leaks; is accompanied by Russian astronaut Anatoly Solovyov (M)

headline.main: U.S. Astronaut Ventures Out On Space Walk

results.snippet: After more than three months on  Mir, the American astronaut David Wolf headed into open space for the first time today to examine the Russian space station's outer hull for possible leaks.    He was accompanied on his space walk by the Russian...
results.lead_paragraph: After more than three months on Mir, the American astronaut David Wolf headed into open space for the first time today to examine the Russian space station's outer hull for possible leaks. He was accompanied on his space walk by the Russian flight commander, Anatoly Solovyov. After a relatively uneventful three hours and 52 minutes, they sealed the hatch back up.

results.abstract: Sen John Glenn, who 36 years ago became first American to orbit Earth, wins his campaign to be rocketed back into space in October, at age 77, aboard space shuttle Discovery; NASA, Glenn and space-medicine experts will discuss plans at official announcement; nation's delight with Glenn's image of mid-American modesty and freckle-faced mastery during first historic mission recalled; photos; Glenn, ever ebullient, has lobbied for two years to make new flight (S)

headline.main: John Glenn to Go Back Into Orbit, at Age 77

results.snippet: In a wonder of aeronautics and geriatrics, Senator John Glenn, the first American to orbit Earth, has won his campaign to be rocketed back into space at the age of 77, space officials and experts said today.    The news that the spry, ever ebullient...
results.lead_paragraph: In a wonder of aeronautics and geriatrics, Senator John Glenn, the first American to orbit Earth, has won his campaign to be rocketed back into space at the age of 77, space officials and experts said today. The news that the spry, ever ebullient hero of the pioneer American space program will go back into orbit for about 10 days this fall -- after his 77th birthday in July -- was an instant source of coast-to-coast smiles of amazement today among Americans who cherish the memory of Mr. Glenn's three-orbit ride 36 years ago.

results.abstract: Barbara Morgan, third-grade teacher in McCall, Idaho, is chosen to be mission specialist in next corps of astronauts, 12 years after she was trained as backup to Christa McAuliffe on fatal Challenger flight; photo of two in 1986; Morgan, now 46 and mother of two sons, has long worked with NASA to promote space exploration (S)

headline.main: At Last, a Teacher Realizes Her Dream

results.snippet: Barbara Morgan's third graders at McCall-Donnelly Elementary School were excited beyond belief this morning when Mrs. Morgan told them she had been selected to be a mission specialist in the next corps of astronauts to be trained by NASA.    ''Can we...
results.lead_paragraph: Barbara Morgan's third graders at McCall-Donnelly Elementary School were excited beyond belief this morning when Mrs. Morgan told them she had been selected to be a mission specialist in the next corps of astronauts to be trained by NASA. ''Can we go with you?'' several students asked as others cheered.

headline.main: Corrections

results.snippet: A caption yesterday with the continuation of an article about Senator John Glenn's plans to return to space as an astronaut misstated the date of a picture of him with a space vehicle in Washington. It was taken in 1987, not this week.

results.abstract: NASA, lobbied by Sen John Glenn for two years, announces that astronaut-turned-Senator will be allowed to journey again into space, and show that 'senior citizens have the right stuff'; NASA Admr Daniel Goldin and Glenn discuss plans for space shuttle flight with Glenn on board (S)

headline.main: Glenn Kept Talking to NASA, and After 2 Years the Agency Said Yes

results.snippet: Saying a persistent John Glenn had finally proved persuasive, NASA formally announced today that the astronaut turned Senator would be allowed to journey again into space and  ''show that senior citizens have the right stuff.''     Mr. Glenn, who 36...
results.lead_paragraph: Saying a persistent John Glenn had finally proved persuasive, NASA formally announced today that the astronaut turned Senator would be allowed to journey again into space and ''show that senior citizens have the right stuff.'' Mr. Glenn, who 36 years ago became the first American to orbit Earth, said he looked forward to his 10-day flight this October, on the space shuttle Discovery, for both personal and scientific reasons.

results.abstract: Sen John Glenn discusses his plan to return to space at age 76, after 36-year absence, news conference; says he lobbied NASA for two years to reprise his epic flight of 1962; doctors report that former Marine fighter pilot, who still has his freckles and Midwestern blend of modesty and self-assurance, is in excellent health (S)

headline.main: Glenn to Slip Bonds of Age in Space

results.snippet: He wears glasses now; he is paler and balding. But he still has his freckles and the Midwestern blend of modesty and self-assurance he always displayed as an American hero.    ''I'll give it my very best try,'' John Glenn said today at a packed news...
results.lead_paragraph: He wears glasses now; he is paler and balding. But he still has his freckles and the Midwestern blend of modesty and self-assurance he always displayed as an American hero. ''I'll give it my very best try,'' John Glenn said today at a packed news conference at NASA headquarters here, where officials announced that they were sending the 76-year-old Ohio Senator back into space after a 36-year absence.

results.abstract: Editorial observes that John Glenn will not be blazing heroic new orbital paths for elderly astronauts on his returnto space, but he has emerged as hero to geriatric set

headline.main: Nostalgia in Orbit

results.snippet: Well, why not send John Glenn back into space? If the space agency could provide shuttle rides for two politicians who controlled its budget in the mid-1980's, if it could send a teacher aloft to inspire the nation's schoolchildren on the ill-fated...
results.lead_paragraph: Well, why not send John Glenn back into space? If the space agency could provide shuttle rides for two politicians who controlled its budget in the mid-1980's, if it could send a teacher aloft to inspire the nation's schoolchildren on the ill-fated Challenger mission in 1986, then why should it not launch a renowned if ancient astronaut who wants a last big hurrah in space at the age of 77, after he steps down from Congress? At least Mr. Glenn has the experience and competence to perform the job. He has been flying his own plane and exercising like a maniac to keep in shape for his rendezvous with the cosmos. This is one old warrior who refuses to fade away. Of course the stated justification for this excursion is mostly nonsense, a fig-leaf rationalization dreamed up by Mr. Glenn during two years of lobbying for the trip and only accepted after considerable pondering by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. There is hardly a burning need to study the effect of weightlessness on an elderly man's physical processes or to correlate muscle deterioration in space with muscle deterioration in the ground-based elderly. If there were, NASA would long ago have rocketed geriatric astronauts into the heavens and would not so readily have jettisoned its old-timers.

headline.main: January 11-17; Blast From the Past

results.snippet: ''I see this as another adventure into the unknown,'' Senator John Glenn ex-plained, referring to the stunning news that, at the age of 77, he will become an astronaut once more. Whether in the interests of pure science or national joy riding,...
results.lead_paragraph: ''I see this as another adventure into the unknown,'' Senator John Glenn ex-plained, referring to the stunning news that, at the age of 77, he will become an astronaut once more. Whether in the interests of pure science or national joy riding, Senator Glenn is to be rocketed up for a 10-day trip in October. ''I'll give it my very best try,'' Mr. Glenn said at a packed news conference at NASA headquarters in Washington.

headline.main: DIARY

keywords.name: glocations

results.snippet: ASIAN TURMOIL, PART I  Try, Try Again  Nothing is simple with Indonesia. The International Monetary Fund thought it had a deal in October to bail out the country and put it on a more austere path. Then came a 1998 budget that imposed austerity on...
results.lead_paragraph: ASIAN TURMOIL, PART I Try, Try Again Nothing is simple with Indonesia. The International Monetary Fund thought it had a deal in October to bail out the country and put it on a more austere path. Then came a 1998 budget that imposed austerity on everyone but the Government and the well connected. High-level visitors flocked to Jakarta to explain to the Suharto Government that this just wouldn't do. On Monday, Version 1.1 of the deal had Indonesia pledging to behave and getting a few concessions on budget surpluses and bank closings. (The latter, the I.M.F. acknowledged, had clearly backfired.) But once again the deal was threatened by rear-guard actions to spare the vast business empires of President Suharto's family and friends from the bitter economic pill. Progressively bigger wigs -- including President Clinton and Michel Camdessus, the I.M.F.'s managing director -- weighed in. On Thursday, President Suharto finally agreed to Version 2.0, with its long list of stringent particulars and much less wriggle room.

results.abstract: Barbara Morgan, 46, chosen by National Aeronautics and Space Administration to train as space shuttle astronaut, stresses she will remain elementary school teacher, phone interview and news conference; recalls serving as backup for Christa McAuliffe, killed in Jan 1986 explosion of space shuttle Challenger (M)

headline.main: For an Astronaut-to-Be, Teaching Remains No. 1

results.snippet: Although Barbara Morgan will be trained as an astronaut to venture into space, she made it clear today that she is first, and foremost, a schoolteacher.    Mrs. Morgan, a 46-year-old teacher at an elementary school, said that even though she would...
results.lead_paragraph: Although Barbara Morgan will be trained as an astronaut to venture into space, she made it clear today that she is first, and foremost, a schoolteacher. Mrs. Morgan, a 46-year-old teacher at an elementary school, said that even though she would finally be fulfilling a decade-old quest to ride a space shuttle into orbit, she did not see it as a career change.

results.abstract: Futuristic Netsurfer series of chairs from Valvomo-Design of Helsinki is aimed at people who spend many hours at their computers; photos (M)

headline.main: Computer Chairs Suitable for Liftoff

results.snippet: THE world of design has something for everyone, but is there a need for a chair a person can't get out of? An eye-catching new computer stand and reclining-desk-chair combination called the Netsurfer, by Valvomo-Design of Helsinki, Finland, sits in...
results.lead_paragraph: THE world of design has something for everyone, but is there a need for a chair a person can't get out of? An eye-catching new computer stand and reclining-desk-chair combination called the Netsurfer, by Valvomo-Design of Helsinki, Finland, sits in the up-to-the-minute window of Moss, 146 Greene Street, in SoHo. The chair promises a relaxing, back-friendly seat for people who work (and play) at home. The designers assume that anyone who wants to surf the Net likes being locked into astronaut position. In other words, the chair is recumbent. Armed with advice from Dr. John Kella, an ergonomics consultant with a Ph.D. in biomechanics, and great expectations, the writer set out for a test -- in the store window. At the top of the checklist was the ease of getting in and out of the chair. That proved to be so important that the test subject forgot the rest of the list. The Netsurfer Classic, upholstered in leather, is the most expensive of three models: $4,995. Lowering oneself into this futuristic-looking chair while straddling the seat is difficult, and getting up from a supine position is hard on the back. ''It's the Harley-Davidson of chairs,'' said Ahti Antikainen, sales manager of Valvomo. ''And not everyone is comfortable on a Harley.'' One sits semireclined on this model with, the promotional material says, ''the computer between the legs like the gas tank of a motorcycle.'' This seat has an adjustable tilt, foot rests, neck and lumbar cushions and lift-up computer shelf and armrests. If only the human body were equally adjustable. The Netsurfer Classic seems best for bikers, astronauts or agile teen-agers. Women should not try this chair in a skirt. Once extracted from the Classic, the tester sampled the mid-price Netsurfer Max ($3,325), which is the same as the Classic, but upholstered in fabric. Again, for the fit and agile. The Netsurfer Light ($3,125), however, has two separate, comfortable units -- chair and computer stand, both on wheels. Getting into the chair is a breeze. A user can work with the computer station or enjoy the chair and workstation separately. Dr. Kella also tried the seats. His assessment was, ''Too much tech.''

results.abstract: Mary Bunting-Smith, Radcliffe president who sought ways to help educated women carve out careers in society not yet transformed by feminist movement, dies at age of 87; photo (M)

headline.main: Mary Bunting-Smith, Ex-President of Radcliffe, Dies at 87

results.snippet: Mary Ingraham Bunting-Smith, the Radcliffe president who sought ways to help educated women carve out careers in a society not yet transformed by the feminist movement and became a mentor to several female writers, performers and scholars, died on...
results.lead_paragraph: Mary Ingraham Bunting-Smith, the Radcliffe president who sought ways to help educated women carve out careers in a society not yet transformed by the feminist movement and became a mentor to several female writers, performers and scholars, died on Wednesday at Kendal at Hanover, a continuing care community in New Hampshire. She was 87. Mrs. Bunting-Smith, a microbiologist who was Radcliffe president from 1959 to 1972, was called Polly from childhood and added Smith to her name after her second marriage, in 1979.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Endeavour, its crew including Dr Andrew S W Thomas, last American astronaut scheduled to live aboard Mir space station, blasts off from Cape Canaveral, Fla, for rendezvous with Russian outpost in space (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Blasts Off With Last American to Live on the Mir Station

results.snippet: The space shuttle Endeavour, its crew including the last American astronaut scheduled to live aboard the Mir space station, blasted off tonight for a rendezvous with the Russian outpost in space.    After several days of worrying that cloudy, rainy...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Endeavour, its crew including the last American astronaut scheduled to live aboard the Mir space station, blasted off tonight for a rendezvous with the Russian outpost in space. After several days of worrying that cloudy, rainy weather might delay the flight, National Aeronautics and Space Administration controllers said skies cleared enough to allow the blazing 9:48 P.M. Eastern time launching that had the Endeavour head up the East Coast as it climbed into orbit for the first shuttle mission of the year.

results.abstract: shuttle docks at space station with astronaut and supplies**Space shuttle Endeavour docks with Mir space station; Dr Andrew S W Thomas, Australian-born mechanical engineer, will become seventh and last American astronaut to stay aboard Mir since program with Russia began in 1995; Dr David A Wolf, ending stay that began last September, greets Thomas with joyous somersault (S)

headline.main: Shuttle Docks at Space Station With Astronaut and Supplies

results.snippet: The space shuttle Endeavour docked with the Mir space station today, bringing the seventh and last American astronaut to live and work aboard the Mir since the program with Russia began in March 1995.    The astronaut, Dr. Andrew S. W. Thomas, an...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Endeavour docked with the Mir space station today, bringing the seventh and last American astronaut to live and work aboard the Mir since the program with Russia began in March 1995. The astronaut, Dr. Andrew S. W. Thomas, an Australian-born mechanical engineer, is replacing Dr. David A. Wolf, a physician who has lived aboard the Russian station since September. Dr. Wolf gave a thumbs-up and waved moments after the shuttle touched, then did a somersault: the orbital equivalent of jumping up and down for joy.

results.abstract: Comment on Sen John Glenn's plan to return to space quotes from possible applications of other politicians to 'Pol-in-Orbit' program; photo (S)

headline.main: We Do Not Have Liftoff: the Outta Space Crew

results.snippet: AMONG the many politicians who sought a seat on the space shuttle, John Glenn was the obvious, perfect choice. He was the only politician with experience, unless you count Jerry Brown. At 76, Senator Glenn may be old, but he's fit, and he won't be...
results.lead_paragraph: AMONG the many politicians who sought a seat on the space shuttle, John Glenn was the obvious, perfect choice. He was the only politician with experience, unless you count Jerry Brown. At 76, Senator Glenn may be old, but he's fit, and he won't be driving. While scientists applaud his homework assignment -- studying the impact of weightlessness on aging -- skeptics wonder if the future will really find Century Village retirees playing shuffleboard on the Mir space station. As delusional space cadets know, the Pol-in-Orbit program was adapted from the secret Enemy-to-the-Moon plan drafted in 1973 by the Nixon Administration. On a newly released White House tape, President Nixon angrily tells the then-F.B.I. Director, L. Patrick Gray, that he hoped to send Archibald Cox, Elliot Richardson and Woodstock's Wavy Gravy on an Apollo flight, ''or any damn spacecraft we've got, manned or monkeyed!''

results.abstract: Article on astronomy photographer Rick Dilsizian notes that his work has been published in several magazines and that he is by profession professor of computer sciences at Westchester Community College; photos (M)

headline.main: The View From/Baldwin Place; Astronomy Photographer's Passion For Recording the Things in the Sky

results.snippet: WHEN Rick Dilsizian was 13, he was obsessed with two things: astronomy and dinosaurs. He is 51 now, and one of those passions is still burning strong. Every chance he gets -- virtually every night that is not marred by clouds or rain -- he goes out...
results.lead_paragraph: WHEN Rick Dilsizian was 13, he was obsessed with two things: astronomy and dinosaurs. He is 51 now, and one of those passions is still burning strong. Every chance he gets -- virtually every night that is not marred by clouds or rain -- he goes out in his backyard here, sets up telescope and camera, and takes pictures of planets, stars and comets. Additionally, he has traveled to all ends of the earth -- Australia, South America, Africa -- to chase eclipses and the better views of things in the sky. His work has been published in Astronomy, the Observers Guide, Sky and Telescope and other magazines. He has had shows at various galleries. By profession a professor of computer sciences at Westchester Community College, he said he loves and takes teaching ''very, very seriously,'' but it is the astronomy that touches the metaphysical side of his being.

results.abstract: Four-and-a-half month mission aboard Mir space station by space shuttle Endeavour astronaut, Dr Andrew S W Thomas, is imperiled by ill-fitting space suit; custom-made Russian suits are too tight; photo (S)

headline.main: Ill-fitting Spacesuit Imperils Mission of Astronaut

results.snippet: Dr. Andrew S. W. Thomas moved from the shuttle Endeavour into the Mir space station today while NASA and the Russian Space Agency tried to figure out how to keep an ill-fitting spacesuit from scuttling Dr. Thomas's four-and-a-half month mission.   ...
results.lead_paragraph: Dr. Andrew S. W. Thomas moved from the shuttle Endeavour into the Mir space station today while NASA and the Russian Space Agency tried to figure out how to keep an ill-fitting spacesuit from scuttling Dr. Thomas's four-and-a-half month mission. At first, Mission Control forbade Dr. Thomas to spend the night aboard the space station and ordered him to stay on Endeavour. Then officials relented, saying that the suit, once altered, should be good enough.

results.abstract: Lawrence K Altman reports on NASA's decision to allow Sen John Glenn to participate in flight into space, to carry out medical research on what will be oldest human body to orbit Earth so far; Glenn, who will be 77 when he is launched on 10-day space shuttle flight scheduled for October, acknowledges that only limited amount of information will be gained from health experiments he will carry out on flight; oldest and newest American astronaut has volunteered for two experiments to assess muscle loss and sleep disturbances during shuttle flight; photo; drawing (M)

headline.main: Studying Aging in Space? Send an Aging Astronaut

results.snippet: BACK when John Glenn joined the astronaut corps, as the United States prepared for its first urgent forays into space, he and his fellow pilots took a notoriously dim view of the men in white, the doctors who could ground them for medical cause.   ...
results.lead_paragraph: BACK when John Glenn joined the astronaut corps, as the United States prepared for its first urgent forays into space, he and his fellow pilots took a notoriously dim view of the men in white, the doctors who could ground them for medical cause. But now that NASA is giving Mr. Glenn one last chance to show the ''right stuff'' in space, he is enlisting the medical profession on his side: one rationale cited by the agency for Mr. Glenn's participation in the flight is the opportunity to carry out medical research on what will be the oldest human body to orbit the Earth so far.

results.abstract: US astronaut Andrew S W Thomas arrived at Mir space station on Jan 24 for 4 1/2-month stay; his crewmates will be two Russian astronauts who will reach Mir soon; Russians have portrayed Thomas as malcontent for saying his spacesuit is too small; they are complaining that he does not speak their language very well; photo (M)

headline.main: Russians Complain Anew About the American on Mir

results.snippet: After first portraying him as a malcontent for saying his Mir spacesuit was too small, the Russians are now complaining that the American astronaut Dr. Andrew S. W. Thomas does not speak their language very well.    After a welcome like this, Dr....
results.lead_paragraph: After first portraying him as a malcontent for saying his Mir spacesuit was too small, the Russians are now complaining that the American astronaut Dr. Andrew S. W. Thomas does not speak their language very well. After a welcome like this, Dr. Thomas may be wondering which side of the hatch he wants to be on when the space shuttle Endeavour pulls away from the Mir space station on Thursday.
